text: every cell has to eat and one way you
carry otic cells do this is by engulfing
molecules from outside a process called
endocytosis it's just one thing
scientists want to monitor in real time
but they've been stuck with static
snapshots because one of their best
tools fluorescent molecules has a
limitation its background fluorescence
which makes it tough to focus on an area
in particular now Donald O'Shay and his
co-workers at University College Dublin
have made nanoparticles that turn
fluorescent only when they want them to
after they enter the cell they've used
these nanoparticle probes to make movies
of endocytosis in human embryonic kidney
cells kept alive on glass slides at the
15-minute mark red fluorescence starts
to emerge from the dark background which
means the particles are entering the
cells and being switched on by hundred
minutes the red fluorescence in each
individual cell concentrates near the
cell nucleus the particles don't enter
the nucleus so that area in each cell
remains dark
